titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to Hellmut Juretschke Papers RG.049
titlestmt.author: Aileen Thong and Megan Bardis

publicationstmt.publisher: Poly Archives at the Bern Dibner Library of Science and Technology, NYU Libraries

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-05-30 14:06:51 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

repository.corpname: Poly Archives at the Bern Dibner Library of Science and Technology, NYU Libraries

did.physloc: Bern Dibner Library of Science and Technology 5 MetroTech Center Brooklyn, New York, 11201 (646) 997-3943 polyarchives@nyu.edu

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated to the Poly Archives by Hellmut Juretschke's daughters, Annette Juretschke Cavajal and Susan Juretschke in February 2022.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is housed in fourteen boxes and arranged into six series: Series I: Academia, 1929-2016 Series II: Brooklyn Poly, 1950-2013 Series III: Instruction, 1985-1997 Series IV: Papers and Conferences, 1941-2018 Series V: Paul Peter Ewald, 1926-2015 and Series VI: Publications, 1953-2018. Original order was maintained whenever possible. However, there was some reorganization of materials for series placement.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Hellmut J. Juretschke was born in Berlin, Germany on August 9, 1924. He earned his PhD from Harvard University and later served as Head of the Physics Department at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, where he earned the distinction of Professor Emeritus. Professor Juretschke's affiliation with the Institute dates back to 1950, when he started his teaching career as Instructor. His scientific interests included crystal physics, surface properties, and electronic structure of metals. After retiring from a career as a physicist, Juretschke published several works of poetry and translation. He passed away in 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Hellmut Juretschke Papers; RG 049; box number; folder number or item identifier; Poly Archives at Bern Dibner Library of Science and Technology, New York University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Hellmut Juretschke Papers contain documents from 1926 to 2018. These documents were assembled by Juretschke throughout his professional career at Brooklyn Poly (operating under the names of Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn (1900-1973), Polytechnic Institute of New York (1973-1985), Polytechnic University (1985-2008), and Polytechnic Institute of New York University). The collection contains professional writings and publications as well as personal writings such as letters and poems. Documents include books, journals, notes, correspondence, papers, and reprints. The collection is 10 linear feet, located on bay 29, shelves 4E-7E. While the NYU Poly Archives houses Juretshcke's professional papers, a donation of his family papers can be found at the Jewish Museum Berlin.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by Polytechnic University in all its forms are maintained by New York University. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the Poly Archives. Please contact the Poly Archives, polyarchives@nyu.edu, 646-997-3530.
